title: Question 31

children: A 64-year-old woman is evaluated in the office after her fourth emergency department visit for stage III heart failure over the past 6 months, resulting in a 2-day hospitalization on two occasions. She lives alone and lacks transportation. She is taking maximally tolerated, guideline-directed medical therapy for heart failure.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

Home-based care includes primary care, nursing, social work, and therapeutic modalities delivered by way of home health services, telehealth services by physicians and allied health professionals, and the “hospital-at-home” model, defined as treatment by health care professionals in the patient's home for a condition otherwise requiring acute inpatient hospital care.
This patient with frequent exacerbations of chronic disease and subsequent emergency department visits would benefit from multidisciplinary home-based care (

). Home-based care includes primary care, nursing, social work, and therapeutic modalities delivered by way of home health services, telehealth services by physicians and allied health professionals, and the “hospital-at-home” model, defined as treatment by health care professionals in the patient's home for a condition otherwise requiring acute inpatient hospital care. Home-based care has shown benefit for COPD, heart failure, and cerebrovascular disease. Although evidence for mortality benefit is mixed, home-based care has been shown to reduce hospital admissions/readmissions and cost, improve patient satisfaction, and decrease the need for institutionalization. Other advantages include avoidance of hospital-acquired complications and improved preservation of functional status.

Hospice is a form of palliative medicine that delivers specialized interdisciplinary care to patients with an expected prognosis of 6 months or less. Hospice care can be provided to patients in multiple settings, including the home, skilled nursing facilities, and residential hospice homes. Hospice teams are skilled in managing the symptoms of advanced and terminal illness and improve overall satisfaction with care. Hospice care may be provided in the home and may ultimately be recommended for this patient. However, evaluation of prognosis and discussions regarding goals of care should precede the decision to pursue hospice care (
). Referral before such evaluation and discussions would be premature.
The effectiveness of nurse-led telephone-based care (

) for chronic diseases is mixed. Although telephone care is an important component of multidisciplinary home-based care, it is unlikely that telephone-based care alone will be able to meet all of this patient's care needs.
Placement in a skilled nursing facility (

) would require the presence of a need that could not be addressed in an independent living setting. The presence of an advanced medical condition alone is insufficient to justify the need for placement in a skilled nursing facility.

objective.__html: Manage a chronic disease using home care.
